name: Convertir des newsletters en podcasts AI avec GPT-4o Mini et ElevenLabs
description:
# üéß Convertir des newsletters non lues en podcasts AI conversationnels

**Transformez la surcharge d'e-mails en aper√ßus audio ‚Äî automatiquement.**

Ce flux de travail transforme les newsletters non lues dans votre bo√Æte de r√©ception en conversations audio engageantes et humaines entre deux voix AI. C'est parfait pour √©couter pendant votre trajet, votre entra√Ænement ou en multit√¢che.

Inspir√©e par NotebookLM de Google, cette automatisation donne vie √† du contenu long en r√©sumant un texte dense en un dialogue naturel √† l'aide d'OpenAI et en g√©n√©rant une narration vocale de haute qualit√© avec ElevenLabs. Le r√©sultat ? Un fichier audio dynamique envoy√© directement dans votre bo√Æte de r√©ception ‚Äî sans les mains, sans √©cran et sans stress.

---

## üí° Ce que fait ce flux de travail

- ‚úÖ Se connecte √† votre bo√Æte de r√©ception Gmail pour r√©cup√©rer les newsletters non lues
- ü§ñ Utilise GPT-4o Mini pour r√©sumer et reformuler le contenu sous forme de conversation
- üó£Ô∏è Envoie le dialogue √† ElevenLabs pour g√©n√©rer des clips vocaux (`voice1` + `voice2`)
- üîÅ Fusionne tous les segments audio en un seul MP3 semblable √† un podcast √† l'aide de FFmpeg
- üì¨ Envoie l'audio final par e-mail pour une √©coute facile

---

## üõ†Ô∏è Ce dont vous aurez besoin

- Un compte Gmail avec IMAP activ√©
- Une cl√© API OpenAI (GPT-4o Mini recommand√© pour le rapport co√ªt/performance)
- Une cl√© API ElevenLabs + identifiants de voix s√©lectionn√©s
- Une **instance n8n auto-h√©berg√©e ou locale avec FFmpeg install√©**
- Connaissances de base sur les donn√©es binaires et la gestion audio dans n8n

---

## ‚ú® Cas d'utilisation

- Convertir de longues newsletters en exp√©riences d'√©coute sans les mains
- R√©utiliser le contenu de Substack ou Beehiiv pour une distribution semblable √† un podcast
- Cr√©er un tableau de bord vocal interne pour les √©quipes qui pr√©f√®rent des mises √† jour audio

---

## üôå Vous voulez aller plus loin ?

Ce flux de travail est modulaire et extensible. Vous pouvez ajouter des √©tapes pour :

- T√©l√©charger l'audio final sur Spotify, SoundCloud ou Telegram
- Publier sur un flux RSS de podcast priv√©
- Cr√©er un digest audio quotidien √† partir de plusieurs newsletters

---

### üì¨ Contact & Retours

Besoin d'aide pour le personnaliser ? Avez-vous des id√©es ou des retours ?

N'h√©sitez pas √† me contacter :  
üì© **Luis.acosta@news2podcast.com**

Si vous construisez quelque chose de plus avanc√© avec audio + AI, comme la publication automatis√©e de podcasts sur Spotify ‚Äî faites-le moi savoir et je verrai comment je peux vous aider !

parameters.content:
## üéß Newsletter-to-Audio Conversation Flow

This workflow turns unread newsletters from your email inbox into dynamic audio conversations between two AI voices ‚Äî inspired by **Google's NotebookLM** ability to summarize and humanize dense content.

### ‚ú® How it works:
1. üì® **Fetch Unread Newsletters** using Gmail (e.g., sender: "your_favorite@newsletter.com").
2. üß† **Summarize and Reformat** the content into a dialogue using an LLM (like OpenAI or Gemini).
3. üó£Ô∏è **Generate Voices** for each part of the conversation using a TTS service (e.g., ElevenLabs, Google TTS).
4. üéõÔ∏è **Merge Audio Segments** into a natural back-and-forth flow using FFmpeg or audio nodes.
5. üì§ **Send the Final Audio** file back to your email inbox (or deliver to another channel like Telegram or Drive).

### üí° Inspired by:
NotebookLM's approach to making long-form text more digestible by turning it into personalized, conversational summaries.

You can modify:
- üéôÔ∏è The tone and voice of the personas
- üïµÔ∏è Email filters (e.g., subject or sender)
- üì´ The delivery method (email, storage, etc.)

> Ideal for turning passive subscriptions into engaging, hands-free content.

---

### üì¨ Need help or want to collaborate?

If you have any questions, need help setting this up, or want to share feedback ‚Äî feel free to reach out:  
üì© **Luis.acosta@news2podcast.com**

If you're looking to build something more advanced with audio and AI ‚Äî such as automatically updating podcasts to Spotify or other audio platforms ‚Äî let me know and I‚Äôll figure out how I can help you!

## üì® Step 1: Get Newsletter Content (Gmail or Webhook)















This is the entry point of the workflow.

By default, we use the **Gmail node** to fetch unread newsletter emails from your inbox ‚Äî perfect for personal automation. You can filter by sender with search "from:" (like Substack, Medium, or Beehiiv) to capture only relevant messages.

### üîÅ Alternative: Webhook for Product Integration

If you're integrating this workflow into a larger product or service, you can **swap this Gmail node for a Webhook node** to receive newsletter or any other content via API from your app or users.

This makes it easy to embed the experience in platforms where users submit newsletter URLs, HTML, or pasted content manually.

### ‚úÖ Expected Output

- `Body (HTML or plain text)`: Main content to be summarized and converted into a dialogue.

## üß† Step 2: Generate Dialogue Script

















This node uses the **OpenAI Chat model (GPT-4o Mini)** to convert newsletter content into a natural, spoken-style conversation between two AI personas: `men1` and `men2`.

### üéØ Purpose
Turn dense, static newsletter content into an engaging, human-like dialogue ‚Äî similar to how **NotebookLM** rephrases documents as friendly, flowing discussions.

### üßë‚Äçü§ù‚Äçüßë Voice Personalities
- `voice1`: Curious, expressive, informal ‚Äî brings humor, reacts with emotion, and keeps it conversational.
- `voice2`: Calm, reflective, slightly ironic ‚Äî adds context, simplifies, and balances the tone.

### üß© Prompt Logic
The custom prompt:
- Sets a clear structure: intro, content breakdown, and closing
- Encourages a spoken, spontaneous tone (not read-from-a-script)
- Uses `<break time="1.5s" />` tags to simulate realistic pauses
- Demands **at least 10,000 characters** (~10 minutes of audio)
- Output is formatted only as:
   - voice1: ‚Ä¶
   - voice2: ‚Ä¶

### üì• Input Source
- Pulls the newsletter content from the Gmail node:
`{{$('Get Newsletter').first().json.text}}`

### ‚úÖ Model Choice: GPT-4o Mini
We use **GPT-4o Mini** for its **excellent cost/performance ratio**, enabling fast generation of long-form dialogue at scale.

> This is the core creative step of the workflow ‚Äî translating static information into an immersive audio script, ready for voice synthesis.

values.content:
=You are the scriptwriter of a podcast that transforms dense written content into a lively, natural conversation between two AI speakers, `voice1` and `voice2`.

Your task is to turn the following newsletter content into a **realistic audio dialogue**. The conversation should be fluid, informal, and engaging ‚Äî similar in tone and structure to how NotebookLM rewrites long documents as discussions. It must sound like two well-informed people exchanging ideas, not like a text being read aloud.

### Roles

- **voice1**: Curious, expressive, casual, often injects humor or everyday references. Tends to ask questions, react with surprise or amusement, and bring lightness to the discussion.
- **voice2**: Analytical, composed, insightful. Adds perspective, context, and a slightly ironic or dry sense of humor. Offers clarity without sounding robotic.

Use realistic, human-like phrasing with brief interjections (`"Right?"`, `"Let me stop you there"`, `"That's exactly it"`). Use `<break time="1.5s" />` tags occasionally to simulate natural pauses.

### Structure

1. **Introduction**: Set the scene naturally. Briefly introduce what the episode is about based on the content, without listing or labeling sections. Present `voice1` and `voice2` through dialogue, not narration.
2. **Content Breakdown**: For each key idea or section from the newsletter:
   - Paraphrase the content in spoken language.
   - Embed the headline or theme organically in the conversation.
   - Include personal reactions, examples, and small tangents to make it relatable.
   - Open loops by teasing questions or ideas that will be answered later in the conversation.
   - Maintain curiosity and variety in tone and rhythm.
3. **Closing**: End warmly and casually, with a brief comment on what stood out or what‚Äôs coming next (no need for formal farewells).

### Requirements

- The script must be at least **ten thousand characters** (about 15 minutes of speech).
- Use **commas** to separate items in a list, not periods.
- Format the output as a single uninterrupted block of text with clear speaker tags:
  
voice1: ‚Ä¶
voice2: ‚Ä¶

You will be given a newsletter input under this key:

{{$('Get Newsletter').first().json.text}}

Generate only the final dialogue script ‚Äî no explanations, bullet points, or headings. Just the conversation in English.

parameters.content:
## ‚úÇÔ∏è Step 3: Split Script into Speaker Segments















This Function node takes the full dialogue script generated by OpenAI and **splits it into individual segments** based on speaker turns (`men1:` and `men2:`).

### üîß What it does:
- Reads the script from the previous node (`message.content`)
- Normalizes line breaks (`\r\n` ‚Üí `\n`) for consistency
- Uses a regex to split the text while **retaining speaker labels**
- Filters out empty results
- Returns each intervention as a separate item with:
  ```json
  {
    "segment": "men1: ‚Ä¶" 
  }

### üìå Why this is important

Each segment will later be passed to the TTS system as a **standalone voice generation request**, allowing different voices to be applied for `men1` and `men2`.

This step transforms a long script into a list of **atomic, voice-ready dialogue chunks**.

## üîÅ Step 4‚Äì6: Loop Through Segments & Generate Voices with ElevenLabs















































This part of the workflow loops through each dialogue segment and sends it to **ElevenLabs** to generate realistic voice audio based on the speaker (`men1` or `men2`).


### üôå Support this Template

If you'd like to support my work and help me continue building free, high-quality templates for the n8n community, **you can use my affiliate link when signing up for ElevenLabs**.  
üëâ It **doesn‚Äôt cost you anything extra**, and helps keep this project alive.  
**[Click here to support via ElevenLabs](https://try.elevenlabs.io/ds0cvdfiufax)**


### üîß How it works

1. **Function Node ‚Äì Clean Segment**  
   - Removes problematic characters like quotation marks and line breaks
   - Stores the cleaned result as `cleanedText`

2. **IF Node ‚Äì Detect Speaker**  
   - Checks if `cleanedText` starts with `"voice1:"`  
   - Branches into `voice1` or `voice2` to assign the correct voice

3. **Function Node ‚Äì Prepare Text for TTS**  
   - Strips the `"voice1:"` or `"voice2:"` label using regex  
   - Outputs a clean `modifiedString` to be sent to ElevenLabs

4. **HTTP Request Node ‚Äì ElevenLabs TTS**  
   - Uses a **custom auth header**:
     ```json
     {
       "headers": {
         "xi-api-key": "YOUR_API_KEY_FOR_ELEVENLABS"
       }
     }
     ```
   - Endpoint:  
     ```
     https://api.elevenlabs.io/v1/text-to-speech/YOUR_VOICE_ID
     ```
    Replace `YOUR_VOICE_ID` with the voice you want to use from your ElevenLabs dashboard. After logging in, go to Voices, find the voice that best fits your needs, and copy the Voice ID by clicking on the three dots [...]

   - Sample JSON body:
     ```json
     {
       "text": "Your cleaned and formatted dialogue text here.",
       "model_id": "eleven_multilingual_v2",
       "voice_settings": {
         "stability": 0.4,
         "similarity_boost": 0.75
       }
     }
     ```

   - You can have one node for each speaker (`voice1`, `voice2`) with a different **voice ID** in the URL.

---

### üîÅ Output
- Each iteration sends one segment to ElevenLabs.
- The result will be a **binary audio file** (MP3) for each speaker‚Äôs line.
- You can later merge them using FFmpeg or the Audio Merge node.

---

> This section is key to giving your newsletter content an actual voice ‚Äî literally! And with ElevenLabs' high-quality synthesis and GPT-4o Mini's conversational structure, the result is natural, polished audio narration.

nodes.name: Function Node ‚Äì Prepare Text for TTS
Function Node ‚Äì Prepare Text for TTS1
Function Node ‚Äì Prepare Text for TTS - Voice 1
Function Node ‚Äì Prepare Text for TTS - Voice 2

parameters.content:
## üéº Step 7‚Äì8: Prepare FFmpeg List and Merge Audio


















This section merges all the individual voice segments into a single MP3 using FFmpeg, following the standard concat workflow via a `.txt` list file.

‚ö†Ô∏è **To use this step, you must have FFmpeg installed and run n8n in a local or self-hosted environment.** This will not work on n8n Cloud or any environment that does not allow executing system commands.


### üßæ Step 7 ‚Äì Generate `concat_list.txt`

A **Code node** performs the following:

1. Loops through all items, assuming each item has:
   - `fileName`
   - `directory` (only for the first file)
2. Builds a properly formatted FFmpeg list:
   ```
   file 'audio_1.mp3'
   file 'audio_2.mp3'
   file 'audio_3.mp3'
   ```
3. Converts the result to **Base64-encoded binary data** so it can be saved using the `Write Binary File` node.

üìù The result is written to:

```
/newsletter2podcast/tmp/concat_list.txt
```

Code logic highlights:
- First item uses full path: `${directory}/${fileName}`
- Others use just `fileName`
- Converts the list to a `Buffer` and then to base64 for n8n binary handling

---

### üé¨ Step 8 ‚Äì Merge Audio with FFmpeg

An `Execute Command` node runs:

```bash
ffmpeg -y -f concat -safe 0 -i /newsletter2podcast/tmp/concat_list.txt -c copy /newsletter2podcast/tmp/final_merged.mp3
```

This generates the final, merged audio file using **lossless concatenation**:

- `-y`: Overwrites existing output
- `-f concat`: Uses FFmpeg‚Äôs concat demuxer
- `-safe 0`: Allows absolute paths
- `-c copy`: Copies streams without re-encoding

üÜï Output location:

```
/newsletter2podcast/tmp/final_merged.mp3
```

Delete the audio chunks and the concat_list

```bash
find /newsletter2podcast/tmp/ -type f ! -name "final_merged.mp3" -delete
```
---

### üìå Notes

- Ensure all audio files are encoded consistently (same format, codec, bitrate)
- If ElevenLabs was used, they‚Äôre already compatible
- If sync issues occur, you can preprocess files with re-encoding (`-c:a libmp3lame`)
- This process assumes FFmpeg is installed and accessible in your n8n environment

---

> ‚úÖ This step finalizes your audio transformation ‚Äî from dialogue chunks to a smooth, podcast-ready episode.

nodes.name: Join audio chucks and delete all files

parameters.message:
=

Hello! Here your newsletter in Audio Version
parameters.subject: =[Audio Version] {{$('Get Newsletter').first().json.subject}}

parameters.content:
## ‚úâÔ∏è Step 9: Read Merged Audio & Send via Email

















This final section completes the workflow by:

1. **Reading the final merged MP3** using a `Read Binary File` node
2. **Sending it as an email attachment** with a `Gmail` node

---

### üìÇ Read Binary File

- Path:  
/newsletter2podcast/tmp/final_merged.mp3

---

### üì§ Gmail Node ‚Äì Send Audio

Use the `Gmail` node to:

- Set the **recipient email** dynamically or statically
- Add a subject and message body 
- Attach the binary file:
- `Binary Property`: `data`
- Attachment filename: `newsletter_audio.mp3`

---

### üìù Notes

- You can personalize the subject with dynamic values (like the original newsletter subject).
- Make sure Gmail authentication is correctly configured in your credentials.
- You may add logic before this node to notify users via Telegram, Slack, or cloud storage.

---

> ‚úÖ This final step completes the journey from unread newsletter to hands-free audio experience, right in your inbox.

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
